user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of send_redirect_fixed_rq_target:
```c
static void
send_redirect_fixed_rq_target (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  char *b;
  size_t fixed_uri_len;
  size_t i;
  size_t o;
  char *hdr_name;
  size_t hdr_name_len;

  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_LINE_RECEIVING == c->state);
  mhd_assert (0 != c->rq.hdrs.rq_line.num_ws_in_uri);
  mhd_assert (c->rq.hdrs.rq_line.num_ws_in_uri <= \
              c->rq.req_target_len);
  fixed_uri_len = c->rq.req_target_len
                  + 2 * c->rq.hdrs.rq_line.num_ws_in_uri;
  if ( (fixed_uri_len + 200 > c->daemon->pool_size) ||
       (fixed_uri_len > MHD_MAX_FIXED_URI_LEN) ||
       (NULL == (b = malloc (fixed_uri_len + 1))) )
  {
    connection_close_error (c,
                            _ ("The request has whitespace character is " \
                               "in the URI and the URI is too large to " \
                               "send automatic redirect to fixed URI.\n"));
    return;
  }
  i = 0;
  o = 0;

  do
  {
    const char chr = c->rq.hdrs.rq_line.rq_tgt[i++];

    mhd_assert ('\r' != chr); /* Replaced during request line parsing */
    mhd_assert ('\n' != chr); /* Rejected during request line parsing */
    mhd_assert (0 != chr); /* Rejected during request line parsing */
    switch (chr)
    {
    case ' ':
      b[o++] = '%';
      b[o++] = '2';
      b[o++] = '0';
      break;
    case '\t':
      b[o++] = '%';
      b[o++] = '0';
      b[o++] = '9';
      break;
    case 0x0B:   /* VT (vertical tab) */
      b[o++] = '%';
      b[o++] = '0';
      b[o++] = 'B';
      break;
    case 0x0C:   /* FF (form feed) */
      b[o++] = '%';
      b[o++] = '0';
      b[o++] = 'C';
      break;
    default:
      b[o++] = chr;
      break;
    }
  } while (i < c->rq.req_target_len);
  mhd_assert (fixed_uri_len == o);
  b[o] = 0; /* Zero-terminate the result */

  hdr_name_len = MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (MHD_HTTP_HEADER_LOCATION);
  hdr_name = malloc (hdr_name_len + 1);
  if (NULL != hdr_name)
  {
    memcpy (hdr_name,
            MHD_HTTP_HEADER_LOCATION,
            hdr_name_len + 1);
    /* hdr_name and b are free()d within this call */
    transmit_error_response_header (c,
                                    MHD_HTTP_MOVED_PERMANENTLY,
                                    RQ_TARGET_INVALID_CHAR,
                                    hdr_name,
                                    hdr_name_len,
                                    b,
                                    o);
    return;
  }
  free (b);
  connection_close_error (c,
                          _ ("The request has whitespace character is in the " \
                             "URI.\n"));
  return;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments in this function that are definitively unreachable (i.e., cannot be executed under any possible runtime/compile-time condition). Reasoning by control flow and conditionals:

- The initial if that calls connection_close_error() and returns is conditional on buffer/size/malloc checks. That branch is reachable when the size limits or allocation fail, and the rest of the function is reachable when those checks pass — so no unreachable code there.

- The do/while loop is reachable whenever the function proceeds past the initial allocation. The loop body is entered at least once by the do/while construct; if the asserted invariants (such as num_ws_in_uri > 0 and num_ws_in_uri <= req_target_len) hold then the loop executes the expected number of iterations. Even if assertions are compiled out, the loop is still reachable (though it might then expose other correctness issues), not unreachable.

- The switch inside the loop contains explicit cases for several whitespace characters and a default case that handles all other character values. There are no case labels that are provably impossible in every execution (the mhd_assert checks only document expected properties but do not make code unreachable). Thus no unreachable case-blocks were found.

- The hdr_name allocation branch (if (NULL != hdr_name) { ... return; } ) is reachable when malloc succeeds; the following free(b) and connection_close_error() are reachable when hdr_name allocation fails. Both branches are reachable depending on malloc outcome, so neither block is unreachable.

- There is no code following an unconditional return that can never be reached; all returns are on code paths that are reachable depending on runtime conditions.

Note: While I did not identify unreachable code fragments, there are places that rely on assertions for safety (e.g., assumptions about req_target_len and characters in rq_tgt). If assertions are compiled out, these could lead to undefined behavior (out-of-bounds reads/writes), but that is a correctness/robustness concern rather than unreachable code per MISRA C:2023 Rule 2.1.
